This is a really tough thing to overcome, and I understand it well. The first thing I would do to approach this issue is check the notification settings in each app you post on. A lot of apps nowadays are making more specific, separate notification sliders for interaction types. If you see any notification sliders for likes, Turn Them Off. This will help keep you from coming back to check and obsess every time you might get one.
  
  Coupled with this, you have to force yourself to do the hardest (and I know, it sounds most obvious) thing: don't bother checking back on your posts. If you're doing things that make you happy, just keep looking forward onto the next thing to post! And then the next. Just don't keep turning back, because you can end up over analyzing and over criticizing yourself.
  
  Every time you get the urge to check, practice mindfulness and awareness. Tell yourself, "this is an urge coming from the self conscious part of my mind, and I won't get better if I keep entertaining it". Set your phone down and carry on with your day. You deserve better from yourself than to keep yourself spiraling down that stressful, anxious path!

He kept saying (to the whole class), "If you're looking away, or hiding your face, try and ask yourself why you're doing that". It's okay to be concerned, but to a certain extent. At the end of the day it's up to the individual what they eat and how they manage themselves. But if this is a close friend, and you know he trusts you, sit him down and ask about it. Don't be insensitive and direct by saying something like, "why are you so underweight". Try to open the conversation a little more sensitively to form a space of trust — maybe ask, "Are you okay". If he asks why you're asking, say something like, "I have been concerned about your wellbeing since you talked about your weight".
  
  It's important to keep in mind that people can be underweight for a plethora of reasons — from eating disorders to conditions that cause weight loss. Since you don't seem to know the cause, it's important to approach this conversation by being sensitive and open ended. Don't throw around things like, "you need to eat more" or "you're too skinny" because frankly things like that are ıgnorant and not needed — they don't help. And don't pry if it seems like he's uncomfortable to talk about it. Leave the conversation open on your end, but let his responses / reactions be signs of when it's time to back off. Just let him know he has  a place to talk about it without judgement.

I wouldn't rush into confessing / asking her out or anything. Spend some time striking up casual conversations! It's a good idea to start talking about common things, like work and such. If the opportunity is present over time, talk about stuff outside of work.
  
  To ease into that, start sprinkling in some stuff about yourself during conversation. Sometimes people feel more comfortable opening up about their personal lives if the other person in the conversation does it first. Some people prefer to keep their personal lives outside of work, however. So if you get signs that she's uncomfortable breaking past that coworker commonplace talk, it's best to pull back and assess the situation. Chances are if she's not interested in talking about aspects of her life outside of work to a coworker, she wouldn't be interested in dating a coworker.
  
  Take your time, be patient, allow room for casual conversations first! And good luck.
